posts.cooked:
Hello everyone, We’ve been having trouble with setting up our CAN network on the CANivore.

we have 15 CAN devices on the network one (1) pidgeon, ten (10) krackens, and four (4) CANcoders.

We attempted to wire it using the standard “Daisy-Chain” Configuration seen here.

We were able to get to the last swerve module, but upon trying to add a 13th device to the CAN , we’d immediately lose the CAN network. all the motors would go from blinking yellow to blinking red. It didn’t matter if we connected one of the two remaining krakens or the CANcoder, the network dropped. we were measuring a resistance of 120 ohm between the CAN High and CAN Low.

we reconnected to the motors/CANcoders and made sure there were no device collisions, and made sure that the issue wasn’t in the firmware. We can repeatably see that extending the network ruins the CAN loop. We even reran wire from another point to make sure the distance wasn’t too high.

When that failed we did an audible and attempted a star topology. A wire splitter from the CANivore split the signal into three–left side of robot, right side of robot, and pidgeon… here’s where it gets interesting. both sides of the robot would work independently if terminated with a 120 ohm, but when connected to the other side of the robot the entire connection would fail.

So on a hunch we installed a second resistor, like so Presentation1 1280×720 19.2 KB

Presentation1 1280×720 19.2 KB

Presentation1 1280×720 19.2 KB

and it worked.  No errors. The resistance measures 60 ohms.  I’m not an electrical engineer, but I can’t for the life of me figure out what is happening. The CANivore is software controlled to have 120 ohm terminating resistor, which implies that the multi-meter should read ~40 ohms instead of the ~60 its reading. Further, I thought it was a continuity error and replaced the 120 ohm resistor with a jumper wire which immediately crashed the network.

I’m positively stumped.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Enable “can termination” in Tuner X on the Canivore

So the second topology works with “ CAN Termination” enabled in TunerX, but shouldn’t, it should have 40 ohm resistance but instead has 60 ohm

it does not work when enabled or disabled for the first topology we tried after adding a 13th device and reads at 120 ohm

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: What type of wire are you using for your CANbus? This year we ran into a very similar situation where we had to add an extra resistor to make it work. We found out after reading the can spec. That, the characteristic impedance of your can wire needs to be at 120 ohms. The line we were using had an impedance of 40 ohms.

vargoose84:

impedance

Interesting, I’ll check tonight after work–thanks

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
vargoose84:

That, the characteristic impedance of your can wire needs to be at 120 ohms. The line we were using had an impedance of 40 ohms.

And just as a caution, in case any readers are not familiar with the distinction: impedance and characteristic impedance are different things. Characteristic impedance is a property of the conductor’s physical and electrical design (related to transmission line theory and propagation of signals, like an antenna). Impedance as measured with a multimeter or the like (whether or not broken down into resistive, capacitive and inductive components) is not the same thing, and will not help you at all here, except for verifying the value of the terminating resistor itself .

Tristan_Lall:

Impedance as measured with a multimeter or the like (whether or not broken down into resistive, capacitive and inductive components) is not the same thing, and will not help you at all here, except for verifying the value of the terminating resistor itself .

Good clarification-- check your characteristic impedance via the spec sheet of the wire.

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: When you get to your shop, it would be great to hear what you found!

posts.name: NatsirtD
posts.cooked: This same situation happened to us at PNW DCMP in 2022, after our CAN bus got hit during our last match. We suspect the CANivore termination resistor was damaged somehow. We ran for all of worlds with 2 120 ohm termination resistors on our bus.

Back in the shop and can check things out

The wire is 22AWG CAN Wire (Jacketed, 25-feet) ( WCP -1153) from west coast products… They don’t have a  Spec sheet on their page Wire – WestCoast Products

can’t verify on-site b/c we don’t have an O-scope

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
Absences of a spec, that wire shooould be good.

Have you tried turning off can termination of the canivore, and having a resistor in the beginning and end?  I know aome teams have had poor luck with the software enabled resistor.
That’s the interesting part, it works with two resistors when the CAN termination is enabled, but does not work with either one or two resistors when the CAN is disabled

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
When the setup “works” are you able to blink all the devices, or are the lights just all orange or green?

Im sure you know as well not to connect a Non-ctre device in the loop as well?

We are able to “Beep” all the motors and seem to be able to control them-- working on setting up swerve at the moment and the wheels at least move.

Everything on the loop is CTRE

Tuned the drive motors-- the CAN appears stable, the robot moves… no idea why it works, but it does.

Good luck everyone. If your CAN doesn’t read 60 ohms, add whatever resistance you need to get it there.

Final update, the bot completed the '25 season with the only failure being the shattering of the 9:1 gearbox mid qualifictions. I cannot; however, conclusively link it to the CAN termination. Outside of any official documentation from @CTRE i’d recommend the posted Feb 25 solution.
